yearPlan.name: Custom Year Plan
yearPlan.desc: On this Journey, Daisies travel the country living the values of the Girl Scout Law; the flowers explore the natural world around them, learning what's local and why that's important. Girls can earn three awards as they experience what's great about their own region and learn to use their own special skills to help people and Planet Earth.

meetingInfo.name: Space Science Explorer 2
meetingInfo.blurb: Daisies observe the Moon and meet the stars
meetingInfo.agenda: [1^As Girls Arrive / Snack^5][2^Opening Ceremony^5][3^Observe the Moon^1][4^Meet the Stars^1][5^Closing Ceremony^10]

activities.name: As Girls Arrive / Snack
activities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Healthy snack items: fruit (strawberries, blueberries, cherries, apples, oranges, bananas), granola bars, crackers, carrot sticks, graham crackers, sliced cucumber and yogurt dip, juice, goldfish, and similar foods

Steps

After they're done enjoying their snack, have the girls help set up for the meeting.

activities.name: Opening Ceremony
activities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law

Steps

If your girls made a day sky book at their last meeting, SAY:

  • Who brought their day sky books with them today?
  • If not, that's ok. Do you remember what the sky picture you drew at home looked like? Was it different from the one we drew in our troop meeting? How so?
  • If you didn't get a chance to draw a second picture, can you describe how the sky can look different when the Sun is up in the morning, at lunchtime, or in the evening?
  • Share with me like the good scientists you are!

Once you and your girls have finished discussing their day sky books, or if your girls didn't make a book, SAY:

  • Today we are going to explore the Moon and the stars!
  • What is one thing you know about the Moon and stars?
activities.materials:
Activity 2: Opening Ceremony

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law

multiactivities.materials:
Activity 2: Opening Ceremony

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law

activities.name: Observe the Moon

multiactivities.name: Make a Moon Sky Book
multiactivities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • The Moon
  • Paper (at least four sheets per girl)
  • Pencils, markers, crayons, glue, stickers, etc.
  • Stapler or simple binding materials

Steps

SAY:

  • Have you ever noticed that the shape of the Moon can look different on different days? What do you think is happening? 
  • The Moon doesn't actually change shape, but how much we see lit up does change! The Moon orbits (moves around) the Earth, and because of that, the Sun lights different parts of it. This makes the Moon look like it is changing shape. 
  • These changing shapes are called the "phases of the Moon."

If the Moon IS visible during your troop meeting, SAY:

  • We are going to look at the Moon and draw what we see--JUST like a scientist.
  • Scientists observe their surroundings and make drawings or notes of what they see all the time--that's how they learn. From these drawings, they are able to discover all sorts of things they didn't know before. 
  • Let's start by making a Moon sky book.

Pass out the paper, pencils, markers, crayons, glue, stickers, etc., then SAY:

  • First, let's decorate the cover of our Moon sky book. Be creative. Your book should represent your special personality.

Once the girls are finished, SAY:

  • Now we're going to look up at the Moon and draw what we see.
  • Bring a piece of paper and some art supplies with you.

Take the girls outside and have them draw what they see. Depending upon the time of year, or if the weather keeps you from going outside, have them look out the window.

Once they've finished, SAY:

  • I want you to take your Moon sky book home and go outside with an adult at the same time on two different days or nights when you can see the Moon in the sky. OR Go outside with an adult at two or three different times on the same day. 
  • Before going outside each time, make a prediction (guess) for what you think the Moon will look like. Then, draw what you see.
  • Be a good scientist and check your prediction. Were they correct? Why or why not? What is your prediction (guess) if you went outside to look at the Moon one more time? 
  • Have an adult help you write down the dates and times you go outside, and any thoughts you have about the Moon.
  • If you can't find the Moon, ask an adult to help you go to NASA's website and look at two different pictures of the Moon. Then, draw what you see! 
  • NASA is a program here in the United States. NASA stands for National Aeronautics and Space Administration. NASA scientists and engineers work on rocket ships, and use tools to learn about the planets, the Moon, stars, the Sun, and everything found in the sky. Their website will have a lot of fun Moon pictures to explore!
  • Bring your Moon sky books back to our next meeting, and just like scientists, you can share what you saw.

Bind the girls' Moon sky books with them. You and your girls can punch holes and tie the pages together with string, or you could staple them--whatever works best for you and your troop.

If the Moon is NOT visible during your troop meeting, SAY:

  • Today we are going to make a Moon sky book!
  • In it, you can make drawings of the Moon, JUST like a scientist!
  • Scientists observe their surroundings and make drawings or notes of what they see. From these drawings they are able to discover all sorts of things they didn't know before.  

Pass out the paper, pencils, markers, crayons, glitter, glue, stickers, etc. then SAY:

  • First, let's decorate the cover of our Moon sky book. Be creative. Your book should represent something special about you.

Once the girls are finished, SAY:

  • I want you to take your Moon sky book home and go outside with an adult at the same time on two different days or nights when you can see the Moon in the sky. OR Go outside with an adult at two or three different times on the same day. 
  • Before going outside each time, make a prediction (guess) for what you think the Moon will look like.  Then, draw what you see.
  • Be a good scientist and check your predictions. Were they correct? Why or why not? What is your prediction (guess) if you went outside to look at the Moon one more time? 
  • Have an adult help you write down the dates and times you go outside, and any thoughts you have about the Moon.
  • If you can't find the Moon, ask an adult to help you go to NASA's website and look at two different pictures of the Moon. Then, draw what you see! 
  • NASA is a program here in the United States. NASA stands for National Aeronautics and Space Administration. NASA scientists and engineers work on rocket ships, and use tools to learn about the planets, the Moon, stars, the Sun, and everything found in the sky. Their website will have a lot of fun Moon pictures to explore!
  • Bring your Moon sky books back to our next meeting, and just like scientists, you can share what you saw.

Bind the girls' Moon sky books with them. You and your girls can punch holes and tie the pages together with string, or you could staple them--whatever works best for you and your troop.
multiactivities.materials:
Activity 3 - Choice 1: Make a Moon Sky Book

  • The Moon
  • Paper (at least 4 sheets per girl)
  • Pencils, markers, crayons, glue, stickers, etc.
  • Stapler or simple binding materials
multiactivities.subtitle: Look at the Moon and draw what you see in your own Moon sky book.

multiactivities.name: Meet the Man (or Woman!) in the Moon
multiactivities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • The Moon
  • Moon Photos
  • Paper
  • Pencils, pens, paint, paint brushes, markers, crayons, etc.

Steps

SAY:

  • For as long as people have been looking at the sky, they have come up with stories about the light and dark areas they see on the surface of the Moon. Some people think the shapes look like a person's face, some see a full body, and others see an animal like a rabbit.

If the Moon is visible during your troop meeting, go outside and have a look. If the weather keeps you from going outside, look through a window. SAY:

  • Look at the Moon. What do you see?
  • Do you see a 'Man in the Moon'? Do you see an animal? A face?

If the Moon is NOT visible during your troop meeting, show your troop the Moon Photos resource. SAY:

  • Look at this picture of the Moon. What do you see? Share your observations just like scientists do. 
  • Do you see a 'Man in the Moon'? Do you see an animal? A face?

After your troop has had a chance to look at the Moon outside, or on the Moon Photos resource, give them a chance to answer your questions. SAY:

  • I'd like for you to draw a picture of what you see. Then, we're going to make up stories about what you drew. You could tell a story about how the animal you saw got to the Moon, or why the Moon has a face.
  • You can work in groups to come up with your stories, and then we're going to share them.
  • You can make a skit, sing a song, or tell your story. There are no rules for how you share.

Have the girls share their "Man in the Moon" stories and pictures. Encourage them to share with their families and friends when they return home.
multiactivities.materials:
Activity 3 - Choice 2: Meet the Man (or Woman!) in the Moon

  • The Moon
  • Moon Photos
  • Paper
  • Pencils, pens, paint, paint brushes, markers, crayons, etc.
multiactivities.subtitle: Look at the Moon and tell a story about the shapes you see.

activities.subtitle: Walk your girls through the activity choices and let them decide which one they like best.

activities.name: Meet the Stars

multiactivities.name: Make a Pretend Telescope
multiactivities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • The Stars
  • Toilet paper rolls (enough for each girl) OR roll up a piece of construction paper, and tape along the seam to make a tube (enough for each girl).
  • Paint, paint brushes, glue, stickers, etc.

Steps

SAY:

  • Space scientists study the Moon. They also study the planets, stars, the Sun, and everything found in the sky.
  • Today we're going to learn about the most important tool for space scientists.
  • Can any of you guess what it is?

After they've had a chance to guess, SAY:

  • A telescope!
  • Today we're going to make our own pretend telescopes and, using our creativity, we'll pretend to be NASA scientists as we observe the sky.
  • Here in the United States, we have a program called NASA. NASA stands for National Aeronautics and Space Administration. NASA scientists and engineers work on rocket ships, and use tools to learn about the planets, the Moon, stars, the Sun, and everything found in the sky.
  • The telescopes we will make won't have powerful mirrors or lenses like the telescopes NASA scientists use. These will limit what we can see to help us focus on very specific shapes in the sky.

Pass out the toilet paper rolls, or construction paper, and art supplies. Then, SAY:

  • Now that you have your supplies, decorate your telescope however you'd like. It should represent something special about you as a scientist.

After everyone is finished, and if the weather permits, take your telescopes outside!

If it's dark outside, SAY:

  • Ok, NASA scientists, raise your telescopes to your eyes and let's look at the sky! What does the Moon look like? (If it is visible.) Be a good scientist and describe it to me.
  • How many stars do you see?
  • What else can you see?
  • Take turns sharing what you see with your fellow scientists.

If the Sun is still out, SAY:

  • I want you to take your telescopes home with you.
  • When it starts to get dark, ask an adult to take you outside to look through your telescope--just like a NASA scientist does.
  • Be a good scientist and share with them what you see.
  • Tell them what the Moon looks like.
  • What else can you see? Describe it to them.

If the weather keeps you inside, have the girls look out the window or use their telescopes to explore the room and tell you what they see.
multiactivities.materials:
Activity 4 - Option 1:  Make a Pretend Telescope

  • The Stars
  • Toilet paper rolls (enough for each girl) OR roll up a piece of construction paper, and tape along the seam to make a tube (enough for each girl).
  • Paint, paint brushes, glue, stickers, etc.
multiactivities.subtitle: Use your creativity and explore like a NASA scientist.

multiactivities.name: Make a Star Pattern
multiactivities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • The Stars
  • Constellations
  • A roll of butcher paper (pre-cut pieces for each girl)
  • Pencils
  • Markers
  • Tape

Steps

SAY:

  • Now that we've explored the Moon, we are going to learn about the stars!
  • For as long as people have been looking at the sky, they've found patterns and shapes in the stars.
  • Have you ever noticed shapes in the stars?
  • Do you know what these shapes are called?

Give them a chance to discuss, then SAY:

  • Constellations!
  • Constellations are patterns of stars in the sky.

Pass out Constellations.

  • Here are pictures of some constellations.
  • Do you see how the stars show the basic outline, and we have to use our imagination to fill in the shape or animal?
  • It's just like a connect-the-dots drawing. Have you ever done one of those? 
  • Look at the constellation Orion.

Point out Orion on the Constellations handout.

  • Do you see how these stars show the basic outline, and then we connect the dots with our imagination so we can see a person? 
  • Today you're going to turn yourselves into Girl Scout constellations!

Pass out the butcher paper, pencils, markers, tape, and SAY:

  • Split into pairs.

NOTE: If you don't have an even number, make groups of three!

  • Help each other tape your paper to the floor.
  • One at a time, lay down onto your paper in an interesting shape.
  • Using a pencil, have your partner draw six to seven stars on the paper at different points of your body. Maybe one could be at your elbow, and another one at your foot. Just make sure they are spread out.
  • Now switch!

As they are drawing their stars, SAY:

  • Because there are different constellations in the night sky during different times of year, farmers would use them to tell when the seasons were about to change. This would help them know which crops to plant and when to harvest them.
  • Constellations also help with directions. Ships would use The North Star, in the constellation Ursa Minor, to find where they were and to help them get where they wanted to go!

Once the girls have finished, SAY:

  • Now connect your stars to make Girl Scout constellations!
  • Do you see your constellation starting to come together as you connect the stars? 
  • Can you use your imagination to fill in the shape? Do you see yourself?
  • Don't forget to color in the stars when you're finished!
multiactivities.materials:
Activity 4 - Option 2:  Make a Star Pattern

  • The Stars
  • Constellations
  • A roll of butcher paper (pre-cut pieces for each girl)
  • Pencils
  • Markers
  • Tape

Make your very own Girl Scout Constellation.

activities.subtitle: Walk your girls through the activity choices and let them decide which one they like best.

activities.name: Closing Ceremony
activities.activityDescription:
Materials

  • Badges

Steps:

Have the girls gather in a circle, and pass out their badges.

SAY:

  • Today you explored, made predictions, and shared just like scientists, earning your Space Explorer badge!
  • Since sharing is one of the most important parts of being a scientist, can any of you share with me something that you discovered today?
  • What was your favorite part about today's troop meeting?
  • What was the best part about earning this badge?
  • What is one thing you can tell me about the Moon?
  • Can you tell me something about the stars?
  • What about the Sun?
  • What other questions do you have about space science? 
  • What else do you want to learn? 
  • Now that we've finished this badge, how do you want to keep exploring? Is there anything you can do on your own? What about as a troop? 
  • When you go home, be a good scientist and share with your friends and family some of the discoveries you made with your Girl Scout sisters.

Share with the girls your favorite part of the troop meeting.

Have the girls choose a song to sing to end your time together.

Have the girls choose a song to sing to end your time together.

overview.str:
Note to Volunteers:

The excitement of running troop meetings for the first time can sometimes be overwhelming. For that reason, scripting is included to help. These "lines" are under the heading "SAY--however, you're the expert. If you feel you don't need the script, do what makes sense for you and your girls.

Your girls may ask you things that you don't know--that's ok! Tell them that asking questions is part of being a good scientist. Brainstorm ways you can work together to find the answers. It's also possible that no one knows yet--maybe your girls will grow up to discover them!

Prepare Ahead

General: Talk to anyone helping you about what they will do at this meeting.

General: Review Women in Space Science to familiarize yourself with resources that can help your girls learn more about women's roles in STEM fields.

Opening Ceremony: If you or your girls need it, print out copies of the Girl Scout Promise and Law.

Observe the Moon: The resource, The Moon, was developed especially for volunteers. Familiarize yourself with the facts and definitions to help you lead your girls through the activities in this badge.

Make a Moon Sky Book: If it's easier for you, create and bind the girls' Moon sky books before the meeting. You can punch holes and tie the pages together with string, or you could staple them--whatever works best.

Meet the Man (or Woman!) in the Moon: If the Moon will NOT be visible during your troop meeting, print out copies of Moon Photos.

Meet the Stars: The resource, The Stars, was developed especially for volunteers. Familiarize yourself with the facts and definitions to help you lead your girls through the activities in this badge.

Make a Pretend Telescope: Get enough toilet paper rolls for each girl to have one.

Make a Star Pattern: Cut sheets of butcher paper (roughly the height of each girl) for your troop members.

Make a Star Pattern: Print out copies of Constellations (enough for each girl).

Closing Ceremony: Be sure to have enough badges for each girl who completed the Space Science Explorer Badge.

Get Help from Your Friends and Family Network

See if anyone wants to lead or support an activity or meeting.

Award Connection

Space Science Explorer Badge

Space scientists are people who study outer space--what's in the sky. Just like a space scientist, girls will explore and observe the Sun, Moon and stars as they look at the sky and talk about what they see!

Steps:

1.     Explore the Sun

2.     Observe the Moon

3.     Meet the Stars

In this session, girls will earn their Space Science Explorer badge.

Meeting Length

60 minutes

The times given for each activity will vary, depending on how many girls are in the troop.

Plus, girls may really enjoy a particular activity and want to continue past the suggested time. As much as possible, let them! That's part of keeping Girl Scouting girl-led!

detailed activity plan.str:
Activity 1: As Girls Arrive / Snack

Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Healthy snack items: fruit (strawberries, blueberries, cherries, apples, oranges, bananas), granola bars, crackers, carrot sticks, graham crackers, sliced cucumber and yogurt dip, juice, goldfish, and similar foods

Steps

After they're done enjoying their snack, have the girls help set up for the meeting.

Activity 2: Opening Ceremony

Time Allotment

5 minutes

Materials

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law

Steps

If your girls made a day sky book at their last meeting, SAY:

  • Who brought their day sky books with them today?
  • If not, that's ok. Do you remember what the sky picture you drew at home looked like? Was it different from the one we drew in our troop meeting? How so?

  • Share with me like the good scientists you are!

Once you and your girls have finished discussing their day sky books, or if your girls didn't make a book, SAY:

  • Today we are going to explore the Moon and the stars!
  • What is one thing you know about the Moon and stars?

Activity 3: Observe the Moon

Choice 1: Make a Moon Sky Book

Time Allotment

20 minutes

Materials

  • The Moon
  • Paper (at least four sheets per girl)
  • Pencils, markers, crayons, glue, stickers, etc.
  • Stapler or simple binding materials

Steps

SAY:

  • Have you ever noticed that the shape of the Moon can look different on different days? What do you think is happening? 
  • The Moon doesn't actually change shape, but how much we see lit up does change! The Moon orbits (moves around) the Earth, and because of that, the Sun lights different parts of it. This makes the Moon look like it is changing shape.

  • Scientists observe their surroundings and make drawings or notes of what they see all the time--that's how they learn. From these drawings, they are able to discover all sorts of things they didn't know before.

Pass out the paper, pencils, markers, crayons, glue, stickers, etc., then SAY:

Once the girls are finished, SAY:

Take the girls outside and have them draw what they see. Depending upon the time of year, or if the weather keeps you from going outside, have them look out the window.

  • I want you to take your Moon sky book home and go outside with an adult at the same time on two different days or nights when you can see the Moon in the sky. OR Go outside with an adult at two or three different times on the same day.

NASA scientists and engineers work on rocket ships, and use tools to learn about the planets, the Moon, stars, the Sun, and everything found in the sky. Their website will have a lot of fun Moon pictures to explore!
  • Bring your Moon sky books back to our next meeting, and just like scientists, you can share what you saw.

Bind the girls' Moon sky books with them. You and your girls can punch holes and tie the pages together with string, or you could staple them--whatever works best for you and your troop.

If the Moon is NOT visible during your troop meeting, SAY:

  • Today we are going to make a Moon sky book!
  • In it, you can make drawings of the Moon, JUST like a scientist!
  • Scientists observe their surroundings and make drawings or notes of what they see. From these drawings they are able to discover all sorts of things they didn't know before.  

Pass out the paper, pencils, markers, crayons, glitter, glue, stickers, etc. then SAY:

  • First, let's decorate the cover of our Moon sky book. Be creative. Your book should represent something special about you.

Once the girls are finished, SAY:

  • I want you to take your Moon sky book home and go outside with an adult at the same time on two different days or nights when you can see the Moon in the sky. OR Go outside with an adult at two or three different times on the same day. 
  • Before going outside each time, make a prediction (guess) for what you think the Moon will look like.  Then, draw what you see.
  • Be a good scientist and check your predictions. Were they correct? Why or why not? What is your prediction (guess) if you went outside to look at the Moon one more time?
  • Have an adult help you write down the dates and times you go outside, and any thoughts you have about the Moon.
  • If you can't find the Moon, ask an adult to help you go to NASA's website and look at two different pictures of the Moon. Then, draw what you see!
  • NASA is a program here in the United States. NASA stands for National Aeronautics and Space Administration. NASA scientists and engineers work on rocket ships, and use tools to learn about the planets, the Moon, stars, the Sun, and everything found in the sky. Their website will have a lot of fun Moon pictures to explore!
  • Bring your Moon sky books back to our next meeting, and just like scientists, you can share what you saw.

Bind the girls' Moon sky books with them. You and your girls can punch holes and tie the pages together with string, or you could staple them--whatever works best for you and your troop.

Choice 2: Meet the Man (or Woman!) in the Moon

Time Allotment

20 minutes

Materials

  • The Moon
  • Moon Photos
  • Paper
  • Pencils, pens, paint, paint brushes, markers, crayons, etc.

Steps

SAY:

  • For as long as people have been looking at the sky, they have come up with stories about the light and dark areas they see on the surface of the Moon. Some people think the shapes look like a person's face, some see a full body, and others see an animal like a rabbit.

If the Moon is visible during your troop meeting, go outside and have a look. If the weather keeps you from going outside, look through a window. SAY:

  • Look at the Moon. What do you see?
  • Do you see a 'Man in the Moon'? Do you see an animal? A face?

If the Moon is NOT visible during your troop meeting, show your troop the Moon Photos resource. SAY:

  • Look at this picture of the Moon. What do you see? Share your observations just like scientists do.
  • Do you see a 'Man in the Moon'? Do you see an animal? A face?

After your troop has had a chance to look at the Moon outside, or on the Moon Photos resource, give them a chance to answer your questions. SAY:

  • I'd like for you to draw a picture of what you see. Then, we're going to make up stories about what you drew. You could tell a story about how the animal you saw got to the Moon, or why the Moon has a face.
  • You can work in groups to come up with your stories, and then we're going to share them.
  • You can make a skit, sing a song, or tell your story. There are no rules for how you share.

Have the girls share their "Man in the Moon" stories and pictures. Encourage them to share with their families and friends when they return home.

Activity 4: Meet the Stars

Choice 1: Make a Pretend Telescope

Time Allotment

20 minutes

Materials

  • The Stars
  • Toilet paper rolls (enough for each girl) OR roll up a piece of construction paper, and tape along the seam to make a tube (enough for each girl).
  • Paint, paint brushes, glitter, glue, stickers, etc.

Steps

SAY:

  • Space scientists study the Moon. They also study the planets, stars, the Sun, and everything found in the sky.
  • Today we're going to learn about the most important tool for space scientists.
  • Can any of you guess what it is?

After they've had a chance to guess, SAY:

  • A telescope!
  • Today we're going to make our own pretend telescopes and, using our creativity, we'll pretend to be NASA scientists as we observe the sky.
  • Here in the United States, we have a program called NASA. NASA stands for National Aeronautics and Space Administration. NASA scientists and engineers work on rocket ships, and use tools to learn about the planets, the Moon, stars, the Sun, and everything found in the sky.
  • The telescopes we will make won't have powerful mirrors or lenses like the telescopes NASA scientists use. These will limit what we can see to help us focus on very specific shapes in the sky.

Pass out the toilet paper rolls, or construction paper, and art supplies. Then, SAY:

  • Now that you have your supplies, decorate your telescope however you'd like. It should represent something special about you as a scientist.

After everyone is finished, and if the weather permits, take your telescopes outside!

If it's dark outside, SAY:

  • Ok, NASA scientists, raise your telescopes to your eyes and let's look at the sky! What does the Moon look like? (If it is visible.) Be a good scientist and describe it to me.
  • How many stars do you see?
  • What else can you see?
  • Take turns sharing what you see with your fellow scientists.

If the Sun is still out, SAY:

  • I want you to take your telescopes home with you.
  • When it starts to get dark, ask an adult to take you outside to look through your telescope--just like a NASA scientist does.
  • Be a good scientist and share with them what you see.
  • Tell them what the Moon looks like.
  • What else can you see? Describe it to them.

If the weather keeps you inside, have the girls look out the window or use their telescopes to explore the room and tell you what they see.

Choice 2: Make a Star Pattern

Time Allotment

20 minutes

Materials

  • The Stars
  • Constellations
  • A roll of butcher paper (pre-cut pieces for each girl)
  • Pencils
  • Markers
  • Tape

Steps

SAY:

  • Now that we've explored the Moon, we are going to learn about the stars!
  • For as long as people have been looking at the sky, they've found patterns and shapes in the stars.
  • Have you ever noticed shapes in the stars?
  • Do you know what these shapes are called?

Give them a chance to discuss, then SAY:

  • Constellations!
  • Constellations are patterns of stars in the sky.

Pass out Constellations.

  • Here are pictures of some constellations.
  • Do you see how the stars show the basic outline, and we have to use our imagination to fill in the shape or animal?
  • It's just like a connect-the-dots drawing. Have you ever done one of those?
  • Look at the constellation Orion.

Point out Orion on the Constellations handout.

  • Do you see how these stars show the basic outline, and then we connect the dots with our imagination so we can see a person? 
  • Today you're going to turn yourselves into Girl Scout constellations!

Pass out the butcher paper, pencils, markers, tape, and SAY:

  • Split into pairs.

NOTE: If you don't have an even number, make groups of three!

  • Help each other tape your paper to the floor.
  • One at a time, lay down onto your paper in an interesting shape.
  • Using a pencil, have your partner draw six to seven stars on the paper at different points of your body. Maybe one could be at your elbow, and another one at your foot. Just make sure they are spread out.
  • Now switch!

As they are drawing their stars, SAY:

  • Because there are different constellations in the night sky during different times of year, farmers would use them to tell when the seasons were about to change. This would help them know which crops to plant and when to harvest them.
  • Constellations also help with directions. Ships would use The North Star, in the constellation Ursa Minor, to find where they were and to help them get where they wanted to go!

Once the girls have finished, SAY:

  • Now connect your stars to make Girl Scout constellations!
  • Do you see your constellation starting to come together as you connect the stars?
  • Can you use your imagination to fill in the shape? Do you see yourself?
  • Don't forget to color in the stars when you're finished!

Activity 5: Closing Ceremony

Time Allotment

10 minutes

Materials

  • Badges

Steps:

 Have the girls gather in a circle, and pass out their badges.

SAY:

  • Today you explored, made predictions, and shared just like scientists, earning your Space Explorer badge!
  • Since sharing is one of the most important parts of being a scientist, can any of you share with me something that you discovered today?
  • What was your favorite part about today's troop meeting?
  • What was the best part about earning this badge?
  • What is one thing you can tell me about the Moon?
  • Can you tell me something about the stars?
  • What about the Sun?
  • What other questions do you have about space science? 
  • What else do you want to learn? 
  • Now that we've finished this badge, how do you want to keep exploring? Is there anything you can do on your own? What about as a troop? 
  • When you go home, be a good scientist and share with your friends and family some of the discoveries you made with your Girl Scout sisters.

Share with the girls your favorite part of the troop meeting.

Have the girls choose a song to sing to end your time together.

materials.str:
Activity 1: As Girls Arrive/Snack

  • Healthy snack items: fruit (strawberries, blueberries, cherries, apples, oranges, bananas), granola bars, crackers, carrot sticks, graham crackers, sliced cucumber and yogurt dip, juice, goldfish, and similar foods

Activity 2: Opening Ceremony

  • Girl Scout Promise and Law

Activity 5: Closing Ceremony

  • Badges

meeting short description.str: Daisies observe the Moon and meet the stars
